Once you get the federal government back to it's few primary responsibilities ....

 
 The problem, of course, is that while those responsibilities are few, they frequently have broad implications -- much broader than the Framers could have anticipated, but then, they did anticipate that such things might happen!
 
 Consider the Commerce Clause (Article I, Section 8). In enumerating the powers of Congress, the Constitution declares that it has the power to "regulate commerce... among the several States" (3rd para). I doubt the Framers dreamed of the sort of multi-million person labor pool we've now got, where technology enables potential employees to interview jobs all over the continent in a matter of days; or an individual consumer buying products electronically with the click of a button from 8 states away; or industrial pollution in one state affecting the populace in a neighboring state; or.... The list of possible interstate economic interactions is not small! (And of course, the part I omitted was the regulation of foreign commerce, which has also grown vastly.)
 
 Don't get me wrong: I'm certainly not arguing for an unlimited government, not by any stretch. It just seems to me that the economy is far more complex and far less localized than it was when the Constitution was drafted, and so Congress needfully has a larger regulatory hand in the economy than the Framers envisioned. Needfully, but also rightfully: for the Framers' real genius, in my view, was in crafting a document flexible enough to adapt to changing historical circumstances.
 
 Which is to say, that that the federal government's "primary responsibilities" encompass a lot.
